comments.timestamp: Ankur sir,

comments.text:
I was hoping and waiting for you to make this video :)
While the concept is nice, to be able to have a 3 months, no cost EMI card, Uni still has quite a long way to go.
The 1% cashback, while sounds nice in terms of actual cash being reduced from the bill, if it is considered to be a
reward rate, is actually less than the ones offered by other major card companies. The biggest plus point for this
card, as of today, is that fuel surcharge is waived off, irrespective of the vendor, hence, there it shines. No surcharge
plus the 1% off, otherwise, there is still a huge scope of improvement. This card is best for people who want to build
up a credit score or are quite new to the credit card game.
Your videos are informative and honest. Thank you :)
Regards.

comments.text:
I agree with most of this except for the loans part. There are exceptions. I am taking today 30Lac @7.8% p.a.
education loan to attend business school abroad, even though my parents can afford to fund me.
(1) India has 5% inflation, so anyway today's 30L is worth a lot less in future. In fact, if someone can get a loan @<5%
p.a. it's free money! At least I would take it with both my hands.
(2) 7.8%-5%=2.8% Now: Obviously I'll work in a foreign country for a few years. I will earn in $. INR weakens every
year. Also, if I repay my education loan I get tax benefit. There is more to save than to lose so why would I use my
own money instead of investing it in some other vehicle when I'm getting a loan? Huge companies like Apple,
Amazon are sitting on billions, so why do THEY take loans?
Regardless, loans are a good thing. We shouldn't circulate a negative connotation with it. I know many of my
classmates (I'm 21 y.o.) who hesitate to take up a loan because it's supposed to be a mark of sham

comments.timestamp: Past performance is NOT indicative of future performance. Many people forget to realize that small /mid cap Index

comments.text:
was under water for 5 years from 2017 to 2020. {negative 50-60% returns} and even crashed 50-60%+ in 2008, that's
enough to test the nerves of even the toughest investors with large risk appetites. The fact is small cap Index
performance comes in bouts of exceptional performance. Not many have those kind of nerves. Definitely a person
having 15k salary shouldn't be advised to invest in small caps. Anyways also don't forget inflation compounds. So
this get 1 crore after  x years won't be much after you remove the compounded inflation. It will be only worth a few
lakhs of today's buying power.
My humble conclusions
- a 15k salary shouldn't be advised to PRIMARILY invest in small caps.
-1 crore has to be adjusted for inflation, then it would be only worth in lakhs of today's buying power.
